    Discovery and Characterization of (8S,9R)-5-Fluoro-8-(4-fluorophenyl)-9-(1-methyl-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (BMN 673, Talazoparib), a Novel, Highly Potent, and Orally Efficacious Poly(ADP-ribose) Polymerase-1/2 Inhibitor, as an Anticancer Agent

    • Bing Wang*
      • , 
    • Daniel Chu
      • , 
    • Ying Feng
      • , 
    • Yuqiao Shen
      • , 
    • Mika Aoyagi-Scharber
      • , and 
    • Leonard E. Post
    View Author Information
    BioMarin Pharmaceutical Inc., 105 Digital Drive, Novato, California 94949, United States
    *Phone: 1-415-506-3319. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2016, 59, 1, 335–357
    Publication Date (Web):December 10, 2015

    Publication History

    • Published online23 December 2015
    • Published inissue 14 January 2016
    https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.5b01498

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    We discovered and developed a novel series of tetrahydropyridophthlazinones as poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) 1 and 2 inhibitors. Lead optimization led to the identification of (8S,9R)-47 (talazoparib; BMN 673; (8S,9R)-5-fluoro-8-(4-fluorophenyl)-9-(1-methyl-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one). The novel stereospecific dual chiral-center-embedded structure of this compound has enabled extensive and unique binding interactions with PARP1/2 proteins. (8S,9R)-47 demonstrates excellent potency, inhibiting PARP1 and PARP2 enzyme activity with Ki = 1.2 and 0.87 nM, respectively. It inhibits PARP-mediated PARylation in a whole-cell assay with an EC50 of 2.51 nM and prevents proliferation of cancer cells carrying mutant BRCA1/2, with EC50 = 0.3 nM (MX-1) and 5 nM (Capan-1), respectively. (8S,9R)-47 is orally available, displaying favorable pharmacokinetic (PK) properties and remarkable antitumor efficacy in the BRCA1 mutant MX-1 breast cancer xenograft model following oral administration as a single-agent or in combination with chemotherapy agents such as temozolomide and cisplatin. (8S,9R)-47 has completed phase 1 clinical trial and is currently being studied in phase 2 and 3 clinical trials for the treatment of locally advanced and/or metastatic breast cancer with germline BRCA1/2 deleterious mutations.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) catalyze the formation of poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR), a post-translational modification that is involved in a number of important biological processes, such as surveillance of genome integrity, cell cycle progression, initiation of the DNA damage response, apoptosis, and regulation of transcription.(1) Among the PARP family members, PARP1 and its close relative PARP2 play essential roles in the repair of DNA single-strand breaks (SSBs).(2, 3) PARP1 is an abundant nuclear protein that detects broken DNA strands and binds damaged DNA through its N-terminal zinc-finger domain, leading to activation of the C-terminal catalytic domain that hydrolyzes NAD+ to produce PAR polymers that extend hundreds of ADP-ribose units.(4, 5) This post-translational modification, referred to as PARylation, promotes the recruitment of DNA repair proteins to the site of SSBs, allowing subsequent repair of damaged DNA via a repair pathway termed base excision repair.(3, 6) PARP2 also resides in the nucleus and functions in a similar manner to PARP1, but it is comparatively less abundant, contributing only 5–10% of the total PARP activity.(7, 8)
    Small-molecule inhibitors of PARP1 and PARP2 are emerging as an exciting class of anticancer agents.(3, 9) Several PARP inhibitors have been reported (Figure 1), all of which are analogues of nicotinamide.(3, 10, 11) These include olaparib (AZD-2281; AstraZeneca/Kudos),(12) rucaparib (AG-014699; Clovis/Pfizer),(13, 14) niraparib (MK-4827; Tesaro/Merck),(15, 16) veliparib (ABT-888; AbbVie),(17-19) and talazoparib (BMN 673; BioMarin/LEAD/Medivation),(20) all of which are commercially available or in late-phase (phases 2 and 3) clinical trials. In addition, several new PARP inhibitors were recently reported and are in preclinical or early stage clinical evaluation.(21-23)
    Not only do these PARP inhibitors show antitumor activity in combination with DNA damaging agents such as temozolomide and topoisomerase inhibitors(24) but many of them also demonstrate the ability to work as stand-alone treatment to kills cancer cells that harbor homologous recombination (HR) DNA repair deficiency, such as those that carry loss-of-function mutations in either the BRCA1 or BRCA2 tumor suppressor gene.(25-29) In addition to inhibiting the catalytic activity of PARP1 and PARP2, some PARP inhibitors were shown to “trap” PARP proteins on DNA and subsequently interfere with DNA repair and replication, resulting in remarkable single-agent cytotoxicity.(30, 32) It was demonstrated that PARP trapping is the dominant mechanism by which these PARP inhibitors kill cancer cells.(30, 32) Not all PARP inhibitors are equivalent in their PARP trapping capacity. In fact, the capacity to trap PARP varies significantly among several clinical-stage PARP inhibitors and correlates well with their ability to kill cancer cells.(32, 33)
    In this article, we report the discovery, characterization, and development of a novel series of tetrahydropyridophthalazinones that led to the identification of (8S,9R)-47 (BMN 673, talazoparib), a novel and highly potent PARP1/2 inhibitor. Compound (8S,9R)-47 inhibits PARP1 and PARP2 enzyme activity with Ki = 1.2 and 0.87 nM, respectively. What’s unique about (8S,9R)-47 is that it achieves antitumor responses at much lower concentrations compared to those of previous-generation PARP inhibitors. For example, its EC50’s in BRCA1-deficient MX-1 cells and BRCA2-deficient Capan-1 cells are >50× lower than the EC50’s of olaparib and >2000× lower than those of veliparib.(20) Analysis by Murai et al. indicated that (8S,9R)-47 is a highly potent PARP-trapping agent,(30, 32) providing a mechanistic explanation for the remarkable antitumor potency of this molecule compared to that of other PARP inhibitors. (8S,9R)-47 has excellent liver microsome stability, good oral bioavailability, and pharmacokinetic properties that support oral, once-daily administration. These properties have enabled this compound to show remarkable antitumor efficacy at low doses in xenograft models following oral dosing, making it a promising anticancer agent.(20)

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Discovery of the Tetrahydropyridophthalazinone Scaffold

    We initiated a PARP inhibitor program to generate prototype compounds to potentially serve as new and more potent PARP inhibitors. Compound 5 was one of the early prototype PARP inhibitors planned for our program (Scheme 1, part A). The original synthesis plan was to begin with 4-nitroisobenzofuranone 6 through the intermediates 7 and 8 to prepare a phthalazinone intermediate 9 and, after bromination and subsequent cyclization, to generate compound 5. However, after multiple attempts at converting 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one 7 to intermediate 8 using adopted literature reaction conditions,(12) we were unable to obtain the desired product. Careful structure elucidation based on 2D NMR and mass spectra suggested that the major product was, in fact, a bicyclic methyl 4-oxo-2,3-diphenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (12), an unexpected and previously unknown compound in the literature. The two phenyl groups were found to be trans to each other on the newly formed ring (as a racemate). It was confounding at first as to how a simple compound such as 7 could be converted into a more complex compound 12 in just one step of our synthesis plan (planned conversion from intermediate 7 to 8). One of the possible reaction mechanisms for this transformation under the given conditions is shown in Scheme 1, part B. We speculated that it involved three unanticipated cascade reaction steps. Specifically, the formation of benzylideneamino intermediate 11a from 7, followed by further condensation of 11a with benzaldehyde resulting in 11b. Then, sodium methoxide opened the lactone ring of 11b, which in turn sequentially led to the formation of an ester and a ketone as well as the ring closure observed in 12.
    Although unexpected, it was recognized that there was still a possibility that this compound could be converted to a potential PARP inhibitor by cyclizing the keto-ester moiety with hydrazine. This would create a tricyclic tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core that could provide hydrogen-bonding and π-stacking interactions to the nicotinamide-binding site of the enzyme, like other existing PARP inhibitors.(12-15, 17-19, 34) It was not clear, though, how the two rigidly and spatially substituted phenyl groups on the tetrahydropyrido ring would impact the binding to the enzyme. Nonetheless, treating 12 with hydrazine indeed gave rise to compound 13 (mostly in the trans form and as a racemate) (Scheme 1, part B). This compound was first tested in a PARP1 enzymatic inhibitory assay and showed an impressive IC50 of 6.1 nM. However, the weak cellular activity of this compound (GI50 > 300 μM) clearly indicated that further optimization was needed.
    Given the good enzymatic inhibitory potency and the structural novelty of compound 13, it was quite desirable to expand it into a series and build a medicinal chemistry optimization program on the scaffold. Assuming that the conversion of 7 to the key intermediate 12 works through the formation of the intermediates 11a and 11b, this synthetic utility could be employed to create more structurally diverse derivatives. For example, one could still synthesize 12-like compounds that have two of the same substituents on the tetrahydropyrido ring in the same manner as in 12 by using different aldehydes in the reaction. More importantly, one could also first prepare an 11a derivative by using an aldehyde and then react it with a second, structurally different aldehyde to make a derivative of 12 with two different substituents on the ring. Potentially, one or both of these substituents could be further derivatized. Together, the biological activity, the structural novelty, and the synthetic feasibility of this tetrahydropyridophthalazinone scaffold could constitute a promising and viable medicinal chemistry platform for a PARP inhibitor program.

    Compound Synthesis

    The synthesis of a small set of compounds (13, 15–19) that bear two identical substituents on the 8- and 9-positions on the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core was carried out according to Scheme 2. Reacting 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one 7 with the corresponding aldehydes in the presence of sodium methoxide in ethyl propionate at a reflux for 18 h led to 2- and 3-bisubstituted methyl 4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates 14a–e in 16–67% yields. Further treatment of 14a–e with hydrazine hydrate gave rise to compounds 15–19 in 21–70% yields (Scheme 2). A selective reduction of 9-pyridyl over 8-pyridyl in compounds 15–17 could then be performed via a hydrogenation conditions using PtO2 as a catalyst at 50 °C for 24 h to prepare compounds such as 20 (prepared from 17).
    The vast majority of compounds in Tables 1 and 2 (24–57) that have different substituents on the 8- and 9-positions on the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core were synthesized according to Scheme 3. Condensation of 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-ones 7, 7a, or 7b with aldehydes in methanol in the presence of MgSO4 gave corresponding (E)-4-(benzylideneamino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one intermediates 21a–l, with yields ranging from 32 to 98%. These intermediates were converted to ethyl 4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates with the 2- and 3-positions bearing different substituents (22a–t and 23a–g) by reacting with a second aldehyde in the presence of either sodium methoxide or sodium ethoxide in ethyl propionate (Scheme 3, steps i and ii). The yields ranged from 5 to 59%. The low yield conversions were mainly observed when the second aldehyde was the more electrophilic triazole carbaldehydes or when benzylideneamino-6-fluoroisobenzofuranones were used. This suggests that a more scalable process or synthetic route might be needed when these compounds become important for the program. It was found that the predominant products at this step possessed a trans configuration for the 2,3-substituted ethyl 4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates; their cis counterparts were either not detectable or too little was produced to be isolated in the reaction mixture. Further treatment of these intermediates with hydrazine monohydrate afforded a group of tetradropyridophthalazinone derivatives (24 and 28–51) that have different substituents on the 8- and 9-positions with a typical yield range from 15 to 80%. Compounds 48–51 that have a dimethoxymethyl or diethoxymethyl either on the 8-phenyl or 9-phenyl moiety were hydrolyzed to give the corresponding aldehyde derivatives 48a, 49a, 50a, and 51a (Scheme 3, steps iii and iv). Subsequent reductive amination of these four compounds using various amines in the presence of sodium borohydride then allowed introduction of either a N,N-dimethyl methyl moiety (25–27) or a cyclic (4–6 membered ring) aminomethyl moiety (51–57) to the 8- or 9-phenyl group (Scheme 3, step v).
    The low synthetic yield of a number of the biologically interesting compounds at the ethyl 4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates (22 and 23) formation step in Scheme 3 severely hampered the further medicinal chemistry optimization and biological evaluation of those compounds. The lack of synthetic scalability would also present a significant barrier for these compounds to advance to a developmental stage. To address the issue, a new route was designed and developed (Scheme 4). A condensation reaction between 6-fluoro-4-nitroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one 7c and 2-methyl-2H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carbaldehyde in the presence of Et3N and Ac2O in 2-Me-THF gave compound 58 in 78% yield. The ring opening of the lactone in 58 by MeOH using AcOH as a catalyst led to the formation of a keto-ester intermediate 59 in a quantitative manner. Isolation and purification of the products for both steps were achieved via precipitation and filtration. Transforming 59 to methyl 7-fluoro-4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate derivatives (60a–e) was accomplished in yields of 73–98% (except for 60c). Again, the trans configuration isomers were found to be the predominant products, and occasionally a low level of cis isomers could be detected in the reaction mixture by LC-MS. The tetrahydropyridophthalazinones 47 and 61–64 were prepared from 60a–e, respectively, by treating with hydrazine monohydrate in a mixture solvent of water and methanol. The products could be collected by direct filtration of the reaction mixture, giving yields from about 30 to 80%. The trace amount of the residual cis isomers formed from the carried-over cis isomers in the previous step could be effectively removed by filtration due to their solubility in methanol. The cis-47 compound was enriched and isolated by combining the filtrate mother liquid from multiple large-scale batches of 47. Up to this point, all synthetic steps in Scheme 4 required no column chromatography purifications.
    Chiral resolutions of a number of biologically interesting compounds, including 36, 42, 46, 47, and 57, were performed by employing supercritical fluid chromatography (SFC) using a CHIRALPAK IA or OJ-H column and CO2/MeOH as the eluents. As such, enantiomers (8R,9S)-36 and (8S,9R)-36, (8R,9S)-42 and (8S,9R)-42, (8S,9R)-46 and (8R,9S)-46, (8R,9S)-47 and (8S,9R)-47, as well as (8R,9S)-57 and (8S,9R)-57 were obtained in yields of 63, 79, 90, 80, and 95%, respectively, and generally with >99% ee. The low solubility of compound 47 in methanol (ca. 9 mg/mL) caused the chiral separation efficiency and scalability of this compound to be less than optimal. We later found that both separation efficiency and scalability could be drastically improved by performing SFC separation for the much more soluble precursor 60a (solubility of ca. 100 mg/mL in MeOH) on a CHIRALPAK IC stationary phase using CO2/MeOH as the mobile phase. The obtained enantiomers (2S,3R)-60a and (2R,3S)-60a could be further converted to compounds (8S,9R)-47 and (8R,9S)-47 by treating with hydrazine hydrate without compromising the chiral purity of the final compounds (Scheme 4, step v).
    The absolute configuration of the active enantiomer for 47 was determined by analysis of anomalous X-ray scattering by the crystal made from the active enantiomer of 47 tosylate salt. An ORTEP diagram of the crystal is shown in Figure 2. The single-crystal structure not only confirmed the proposed tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core structure but also showed an absolute configuration of R and S at C1 (9-position) and C2 (8-position), respectively. On the basis of this information, the absolute stereo configuration of the active enantiomer of 47 can be assigned as (8S,9R)-47. The inactive enantiomer of 47, with the (8R,9S) configuration, was named LT-00674.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Structure–Activity Relationship (SAR) and Lead Optimization

    All synthesized analogues were evaluated for PARP-1 enzymatic inhibitory activity using rucaparib (AG-014699) as the reference standard in the assay.(20) In addition to the PARP-1 inhibition assay, many compounds were tested in three additional functional assays: a cellular PARylation assay to assess their ability to inhibit intracellular PARP1/2 activity, a TMZ sensitization assay to examine their ability to potentiate cell killing by temozolomide, and a Capan-1 cytotoxicity assay to measure the single-agent anticancer activity in BRCA2-mutation background. A number of the selected compounds were also assessed for their metabolic stability in rat liver microsomes. Our initial efforts to generate analogues attempted to replace the 8- and 9-phenyl groups of the early intermediate 13 with a pair of identical heteroaryl moieties for better solubility and cellular activities (Scheme 1). Unfortunately, it was found that 15–18, wherein the heteroaryls are pyridyls or imidazole, displayed much reduced inhibitory activities, with IC50’s ranging from ∼20 to ∼100 nM (Table 2) compared to 6.1 nM for 13. To examine whether the aromatic moieties at the 8- or 9-position could be replaced by nonaromatic ones, compounds 20 and 33 were prepared and assayed. The data indicate that such a replacement is not well-tolerated (Table 2). For example, generation of compound 20 from 17 resulted in a roughly 6-fold drop in its enzymatic potency, from IC50 = 17.7 to 105 nM. More drastically, changing the 9-phenyl in 13 to 9-isopropyl in 33 resulted in a virtually inactive IC50 of 4.139 μM of the latter. Similar replacements at the 8-position also led to a similar activity loss (data not shown).
    We thus turned our attention to exploring SAR by incorporating various substituents onto the phenyl groups of compound 13. First, a small set of compounds having identical substitutions of an N,N-dialkylamino methyl or N-methylamino methyl group on both the 8- and 9-phenyl was examined. Compound 19 was one of the examples, in which N,N-dimethylamino methyl was placed on the para position of the two phenyls. As a result, compound 19 not only displayed good enzymatic inhibitory activity (IC50 = 3.89 nM) but also elicited cellular activities including a single-agent EC50 of 0.979 μM in the Capan-1 cytotoxicity assay (Table 1). Encouraged by this finding, we next explored compounds 24–27 in which just one N,N-dimethylamino methyl group was substituted at either the 8- or 9-phenyl group on the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core. Compound 25 with N,N-dimethylamino methyl substituted at the para position of 8-phenyl demonstrated a rather attractive in vitro activity profile, with an IC50 = 2.36 nM in PARP1 inhibition, EC50 = 6 nM in a PARylation assay, GI50 = 59 μM in a TMZ potentiation assay, and EC50 = 0.387 μM as a single agent in the Capan-1 assay, which are comparable to those from the reference compound rucaparib (AG-014699) (Table 1). Interestingly, when the same substitution was swapped to a 9-phenyl group to give 24, reduced enzyme inhibitory potency and potentiation activity with TMZ were observed (IC50 = 5.85 nM and GI50 = 112 μM). Likewise, another similar pair of compounds, 26 and 27 (with IC50 = 3.65, 2.63 and GI50 = 204, 128 nM, respectively), in which the same substitution was switched to the meta position of 9- and 8-phenyls, respectively, also seemed to suggest that the substitution at 8-phenyl could provide more favorable activities.
    Compound 25 showed interesting biological activities, but its metabolic stability was less than optimal, with a half-life of 12 min in rat liver microsomes (Table 1; rLM). In order to improve its metabolic stability, two subsets of compounds were synthesized and evaluated. The examples of the first set consisted of 28, 29, 30, and 52, in which 8-(4-dimethylamino methyl)phenyl was kept for every compound, and the substitution of isopropyl, methyl, trifluoromethyl, and fluoro was introduced, respectively, to the para position of 9-phenyl (Table 1). The substitution of isopropyl and trifluoromethyl on the 9-phenyl appeared to be slightly detrimental, as evidenced by the reduced enzymatic inhibitory activity for 28 (IC50 = 9.59 nM) and 30 (IC50 = 6.29 nM). While enzymatic activity was quite comparable among 25, 29, and 52, certain metabolic stability improvements were noticed for methyl-substituted 29 (rLM t1/2 = 35 min) and fluoro-substituted 52 (rLM t1/2 = 44 min) over the original lead 25 (rLM t1/2 = 12 min). It is speculated that such enhancement of metabolic stability is probably achieved by blocking a potential para-hydroxylation on the 9-phenyl. This was further confirmed by another matched molecular pair, 31 and 32, in which the only structural difference is 9-phenyl for 31 vs 9-fluorophenyl for 32, with half-lives of 5 vs 82 min, respectively, in rat liver microsomes. It was also noted that 31 and 32 both bear a 5-fluoro substitution on the tricyclic core and yielded a more favorable single-agent activity in the Capan-1 assay than the other 5-desfluoro compounds within the set despite their comparable enzymatic activities. The second subset of compounds, 53–57, was made to exploit the replacement of N,N-dimethylamino methyl with the cyclic amino methyl moieties on the para position of the 8-phenyl (Table 1). Specifically, 4-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)methyl for 53, 4-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)methyl for 54, and 4-(azetidin-1-yl)methyl for 55 replaced the dimethylaminomethyl moiety in 25; compounds 56 and 57 were derived from 54 and 55 by replacing the 9-phenyl with 9-fluorophenyl. Overall, such modifications did not affect the in vitro potency and metabolic stability very much for 53–56. However, compound 57 (rLM t1/2 = 89 min), structurally similar to 32, also achieved a similar degree of metabolic stability improvement from 25 while retaining the excellent in vitro potency. Altogether, those compounds, including 19, 29, 32, 52, and 57, in which the para position of 9-phenyl is blocked by groups such as fluoro, methyl, or dimethylamino methyl, all demonstrated an improved metabolic stability over the unsubstituted 9-phenyl analogue 25, suggesting that the para position of the 9-phenyl might be a metabolic soft spot, presumably for hydroxylation (Table 1).
    Table 1. In Vitro Activity and Metabolic Stability of 8,9-Diphenyl Derived Tetrahydropyridophthalazinone Compounds
    compoundR1R2R3PARP-1 enzyme IC50 (nM)acellular PAR inhibition EC50 (nM)bTMZ chemosensitizationd GI50 (μM)bCapan-1 (BRCA2 mutant) EC50 (μM)brLM t1/2 (min)a
    13HHH6.158.43242.97 
    24H4-CH2NMe2H5.85 112 6
    254-CH2NMe2HH2.366590.38712
    26H3-CH2NMe2H3.65 204 11
    273-CH2NMe2HH2.63 128  
    194-CH2NMe24-CH2NMe2H3.8918.6630.979>120

    524-CH2NMe24-FH2.4818.5761.7344

    a

    Mean of duplicate determinations.

    b

    Mean of triplicate determinations.

    d

    TMZ sensitization conditions: the concentration (μM) of TMZ that kills 50% of the treated cells (GI50) in the presence of 0.4 μM PARP inhibitors

    In light of this finding and in order to further enhance metabolic stability, we designed and synthesized another series of compounds in which a few, presumably metabolically less labile, azole moieties were introduced to the 9-position (Table 2). Compound 35 was derived from 13 by using a 1-methyl-imidazol-2-yl moiety in lieu of 9-phenyl. As the first compound in the series, it displayed a rather promising biological profile (comparable to that of the reference compound rucaparib (AG-014699)). This included excellent enzymatic activity (IC50 = 2.35 nM), moderate to good cellular activities in PARylation (EC50 = 16.9 nM), TMZ potentiation (GI50 = 97 μM), single-agent Capan-1 cytotoxicity (EC50 = 0.36 μM), and good metabolic stability (rLM t1/2 = 89 min) (Table 2). Recognizing that the para position of the 8-phenyl might also be a potential metabolic soft spot, we next introduced a fluorine to block this position in compound 36. As a result, the metabolic stability, indeed, was further enhanced (rLM t1/2 > 120 min) without compromising other biological activities. Further incorporating 5-fluoro onto 36 generated compound 42, which was as potent as 36 in enzymatic inhibition (IC50 = 1.87 nM), cellular PARylation (EC50 = 17 nM), and chemosensitization (GI50 = 35.7 μM). However, as in the cases of 31 and 32, the 5-fluoro-substituted compound 42 again demonstrated an evident enhancement of single-agent activity in Capan-1 cancer cells (EC50 = 0.056 μM), showing about a 7-fold potency increase over 36. In contrast, 5-position modifications with a substitution other than fluorine, such as chlorine, bromine, methyl, and methoxy, all led to a certain degree of activity reduction. For example, 41, a 5-chloro-substituted derivative of 37, displayed an activity profile of PARP1 IC50 = 6.18 nM, cellular PARylation EC50 = 121 nM, TMZ sensitization GI50 = 111 μM, and single-agent Capan-1 EC50 = 0.785 μM. The 5-fluoro-substituted 37 yielded an enzymatic inhibition IC50 of 2.14 nM, PARylation EC50 of 18.1 nM, TMZ potentiation GI50 of 36.3 μM, and single -agent activity EC50 of 0.247 μM. Similar detrimental effects were reported for a 5-substitution that is bulkier than hydrogen and fluorine in other PARP inhibitors in the literature.(19, 35)
    Besides a 9-imidazole group, analogues with other 9-azoles were also exploited (Table 2). Compound 38 bearing 9-(thiazol-2-yl) showed an enzymatic IC50 of 7.35 nM, a slight reduction compared to that of 36 (IC50 = 2.08 nM). Compound 39 having a 9-(1-methyl-pyrazol-5-yl) substitution demonstrated an equipotent enzymatic inhibitory activity compared to that of 36, with an IC50 of 1.84 nM. However, its single-agent activity in Capan-1 cells (EC50 = 0.956 μM) was somewhat decreased from that of 36 (EC50 = 0.418 μM). A similar trend but with a more amplified effect was also observed for compound 45, in which the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core was substituted with 8-phenyl and 9-(4-methyl-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl) groups. It displayed a potent enzymatic inhibitory activity (IC50 = 2.76 nM) but a much reduced single-agent activity in the Capan-1 assay (EC50 = 4.34 μM). Interestingly, despite a subtle structural difference between 43 and 45, 9-(1-methyl-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl) vs 9-(4-methyl-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl), their single-agent activity difference is rather significant, an EC50 = 0.17 μM for 43 vs EC50 = 4.34 μM for 45, about a 25-fold difference. Compound 43 is also metabolically quite stable (rLM t1/2 = 414 min). With this newly identified lead, further structural refinements were performed by employing the previously gained SAR knowledge. First, replacing the 8-phenyl with 8-(4-fluorophenyl) in 43 resulted in compound 46 that elicited about the same enzymatic activity (IC50 = 2.29 nM) as that of 43 but had improved cellular activities, including PARylation (EC50 = 6.94 nM), chemosensitization (GI50 = 44 μM), and single-agent cytotoxicity (EC50 = 0.071 μM) (Table 2). Moreover, when 5-fluoro was introduced to 43, leading to compound 44, the single-agent cytotoxicity was further reduced to a single-digit nanomolar range (EC50 = 0.009 μM), representing about a 19-fold potency increase over that of lead compound 43. In view of the excellent biological activities measured for 44 and 46, the next logical extension was to make a compound in which the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core was substituted with 5-fluoro, 8-(4-fluorophenyl), and 9-(1-methyl-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl) moieties. This substitution led to compound 47 (Table 2), which indeed retained the enzymatic (IC50 = 2.14 nM) and cellular PARylation (EC50 = 5.48 nM) activities as well as the metabolic stability (rLM t1/2 = 359 min), but, more importantly, it achieved a remarkable cytotoxicity either as a single agent in Capan-1 cells (EC50 = 0.008 μM) or in combination with TMZ in the chemosensitization assay (GI50 = 19 μM). It is the most potent compound that we have identified thus far in this series.

    Stereospecific Inhibitory Activity

    Disubstitution at the 8- and 9-positions on the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core creates not only trans and cis isomers but also two chiral centers. Fortunately, the thermodynamically more favorable trans isomers are always the predominant products in the synthesis, and, importantly, the cis isomers are far less active than their trans counterparts. For example, the cis isomers (8S,9S and 8R,9R were not separated) of 47 showed a rather weak activity with PARP1 (IC50 = 44.9 nM). All of the trans compounds made and evaluated up to this point are racemates. Given the activity differences between the trans and cis isomers, it is conceivable that one of the enantiomers in a trans racemate might yield a more favorable inhibition activity. We thus selected a set of leading racemate compounds, including 36, 42, 46, 47, and 57, for chiral resolution. The in vitro activities from the resulting five pairs of enantiomers after the chiral resolutions are shown in Table 3. Evidently, one of the two enantiomers in every pair demonstrated drastically better in vitro activities than its mirror image isomer. This indicated that the binding interactions of the tetrahydropyridophthalazinone derivatives to the PARP enzyme are indeed stereospecific. It was noted that the degree of the differential activities between the two enantiomers appeared to be compound-dependent, ranging from a few fold to a few hundred fold among the five pairs of the stereoisomers in both enzymatic and cellular activities. The largest activity separation was found for the enantiomer pair resolved from 47, showing a strikingly more than 200-fold potency difference across the enzymatic, cellular PARylation, TMZ sensitization, and Capan-1 assays (Table 3). The absolute stereo configuration of the active enantiomer resolved from racemate 47 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction to have an 8S,9R configuration and therefore was assigned as (8S,9R)-47. On the basis of this information, the same stereo configurations were assigned to other active enantiomers for the remaining four pairs. Compound (8S,9R)-47, the sole compound with single-digit nanomolar inhibitory activities in all assays, was the most potent compound in the set and was approximately 2-fold as active as the racemate 47 (Table 3). All other active enantiomers including (8S,9R)-36, (8S,9R)-42, (8S,9R)-46, and (8S,9R)-57 have also shown comparable or better in vitro potency in comparison with that of known clinic PARP inhibitors. Furthermore, we found that (8S,9R)-47 inhibits PARP1 and PARP2 with a similar potency (Ki = 1.2 nM for PARP1 and Ki = 0.85 nM for PARP2), which is likely due to the sequence similarity in the catalytic domains of the two enzymes.
    Table 3. In Vitro Activity for the Selected Enantiomer Pairs
    compoundenantiomeric purity (% ee)PARP-1 enzyme IC50 (nM)acellular PAR inhibition EC50 (nM)bTMZ chemosensitizationd GI50 (nM)bCapan-1 (BRCA2 deficient) EC50 (nM)b
    (8R,9S)-3698.7136285>10 0006310
    (8S,9R)-3699.22.256.9261305
    (8R,9S)-4210022.4164104124
    (8S,9R)-4299.11.617.92539
    (8S,9R)-461001.465.14137
    (8R,9S)-4698.668.925032631883
    (8S,9R)-571001.16.3279389
    (8R,9S)-5799.55.611.835722249
    (8S,9R)-4799.30.572.5145
    (8R,9S)-4799.214486418071135

    b

    Mean of triplicate determinations.

    d

    TMZ sensitization conditions: the concentration (nM) of a PARP inhibitor that kills 50% of the treated cells (GI50) in the presence of 200 μM TMZ is reported.

    Intriguingly, the high sensitivity of enzyme inhibitory activity to the stereo configuration in our series was not observed in other PARP inhibitors in the clinic. For example, both veliparib (ABT-888) and niraparib (MK-4827) contain one chiral center, but their R and S enantiomers are virtually equipotent in inhibiting PARP1 enzyme.(15, 16, 19) Such distinct stereo specificity in our PARP inhibitors might arise from the rigidly locked dual asymmetric configurations at the 8- and 9-positions, creating additional and/or unique interactive contacts outside the nicotinamide-binding pocket in the PARP protein. This notion was confirmed later in the co-crystal structural studies of (8S,9R)-47 with PARP1 and PARP2, vide infra.(36)

    Cellular Cytotoxicity

    Throughout the lead optimization process, another intriguing finding was that while many compounds in the 8- and 9-aryl-disubstituted tetrahydropyridophthalazinone series were similarly potent in PARP inhibition (in the enzyme assay and in the cellular PARylation assay), they behaved quite differently regarding cytotoxicity either as a single agent in the Capan-1 assay or as a chemosensitizer in the TMZ assay. Examples included the matched molecular pairs of 32 and 52, 36 and 42, 43 and 45, and 46 and 47 (Tables 1 and 2). This phenomenon was also observed among other known PARP inhibitors in clinical development(12-15, 17-19) and becomes even more evident for (8S,9R)-47,(20) as shown in Table 4. Specifically, despite their quite comparable enzymatic and cellular PARylation inhibitory activities, (8S,9R)-47 is 59-fold, 35-fold, and 1500-fold more effective in enhancing cytotoxicity with TMZ relative to olaparib (AZD-2281), rucaparib (AG-014699), and veliparib (ABT-888), respectively. Likewise, (8S,9R)-47 also displayed activity as a single agent in BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutant cell-killing assays that was magnitudes greater when compared in parallel with that of other PARP inhibitors such as veliparib (ABT-888), rucaparib (AG-014699), niraparib (MK-4827), and olaparib (AZD-2281), making it the most cytotoxic PARP inhibitor in clinical development (Table 4).
    Table 4. In Vitro Activity Comparison of (8S,9R)-47 with Other PARP Inhibitors in Clinical Development
    compoundPARP-1 enzyme IC50 (nM)acellular PAR inhibition EC50 (nM)bTMZ chemosensitizationd GI50 (nM)bMX-1 cell (BRCA1 mutant) EC50 (nM)bCapan-1 cell (BRCA2 mutant) EC50 (nM)bMRC-5 (normal) EC50 (μM)
    Veliparib4.735.946203ND>10 000 > 10
    Rucaparib1.984.691445.36098.53
    Olaparib1.943.5723723.22595.83
    Nicaparib8.05NDNDND650ND
    (8S,9R)-470.572.5140.350.31
    a

    Mean of duplicate determinations.

    b

    Mean of triplicate determinations.

    d

    TMZ sensitization conditions: the concentration (nM) of a PARP inhibitor that kills 50% of the treated cells (GI50) in the presence of 200 μM TMZ is reported.

    It is extremely unlikely that such magnitudes of discrepancy in cytotoxicity are attributed to catalytic inhibition capabilities alone. Instead, a recently proposed PARP–DNA complex trapping hypothesis may offer a plausible explanation.(30, 32, 33) This concept suggests that certain PARP inhibitor structures may induce allosteric conformational changes in the enzyme, thereby stabilizing its association with damaged DNA. This, in turn, prevents DNA replication and transcription, killing cancer cells more effectively than catalytic inhibition alone. Recent studies by others have revealed that the potency to trap PARP–DNA complexes varies widely across different PARP inhibitors but correlates quite well with the rank order of cytotoxicity. For example, while veliparib (ABT-888) exhibits little trapping activity, (8S,9R)-47 displays a PARP–DNA complex trapping efficiency that is about 100-fold more than that of olaparib (AZD-2281), niraparib (MK-4827), and rucaparib (AG-014699), making it the most potent trapper known to date.(32)

    Structural Basis for Binding of Tetrahydropyridophthlazinones to PARP1

    A recently published X-ray co-crystal structure of the PARP1 catalytic domain (catPARP1) bound to (8S,9R)-47 (BMN 673; talazoparib)(36) provides insight into the differential inhibitory potencies among the series of tetrahydropyridophthlazinones described here. In particular, the observed dependence of inhibitory activity on distinct stereospecificity and heterocyclic structures of the novel tripartite chemical scaffold can be partly explained by unique binding interactions formed by the inhibitor’s 8S-(p-fluorophenyl) and 9R-triazole substituents in the NAD+ site (Figure 3a). As reported in the co-crystal structure(36) and reproduced in the calculated docked model, the active trans-(8S,9R) configuration, as in (8S,9R)-47, allows the fluorophenyl and 1,2,4-triazole groups to form unprecedented π-stacking and water-mediated hydrogen-bonding interactions with Tyr889 and Tyr896, respectively (Figure 3a). Molecular docking of the less potent enantiomer, trans-(8R,9S)-47 or LT-00674 (Table 3), results in a noticeable displacement of the bound ligand within the NAD+ site (Figure 3b). While maintaining the conserved π-stacking and hydrogen-bonding interactions with key PARP1 residues (His862, Gly863, Ala898, Lys903, Ser904, Tyr907, and Glu988), the orientation and position of the 8R-fluorophenyl and 9S-triazole groups deviate significantly from that observed with (8S,9R)-47 (Figure 3b). Such displacements would cause steric clashes, causing the repositioning of PARP1 residues, including the prominent π-stacking with Tyr907, as illustrated in the induced-fit docked model (Figure 3b). Moreover, the 9S-triazole group in the predicted binding pose no longer participates in the water-mediated hydrogen-bonding interaction with the backbone of Tyr896 (Figure 3b). These marked structural changes, predicted by molecular docking, may be a plausible factor that contributes to the distinct (8S,9R) stereospecificity in these tetrahydropyridophthalazinone derivatives (Table 3).
    Ordered active-site water molecules contribute to an intricate network of hydrogen-bonding and π-stacking interactions formed between catPARP1 and (8S,9R)-47.(36) Nitrogen atoms on both the tricyclic tetrahydropyridophthalazinone core (N1 and N7) and 9R-heterocyclic 1,2,4-triazole group (N4) form hydrogen bonds with the ordered water molecules, which, in turn, can interact with the PARP1 active-site residues, such as Glu988 and Tyr896 (Figure 3a). Interestingly, nitrogen atoms at positions 1, 2, and 4 on the 9R-triazole ring appear to contribute to the distinct inhibitory and/or cytotoxicity potencies among (8S,9R)-47 and its related compounds. For example, removal of the N4 atom alone, as in (8S,9R)-39, significantly reduces single-agent cancer cell-killing activity without affecting enzymatic inhibition potency (Table 2). Substitution of this hydrogen-bonding N4 atom by carbon in (8S,9R)-39 would require displacement of its 9-substituent away from the ordered active-site water molecule or vice versa; the latter case was predicted in the docked model, in which the conserved active-site water molecule moved away from both the bound ligand and Tyr896 (Figure 3c). Elucidation of the functional consequences of the environmental changes around the 9R-triazole group, especially on the inhibitor’s cytotoxic potencies, awaits further studies. In aggregate, several critical aspects of SAR among these tetrahydropyridophthalazinone derivatives are likely directly related to the fine-tuned stereospecific packing and hydrogen-bonding network formed by the unique tripartite scaffold at the NAD+-binding site (Figure 3a). Notably, the novel interactions formed by stereospecific, dibranched (8S,9R)-47 at the outer borders of the inhibitor-binding pocket have been suggested to influence PARP1’s conformational flexibility, which is possibly involved in the interdomain communication, PARP1–DNA trapping activity, and cytotoxicity potency.(33)

    Pharmacokinetic and in Vitro Safety Properties

    The excellent in vitro biological and metabolic profiles of the top lead compounds warranted further assessment of their PK properties. As shown in Table 5, with the exception of the only nonazole derivative (8S,9R)-57, all other compounds demonstrated excellent oral bioavailability ranging from 47 to 91% after oral exposure in Sprague–Dawley rats. All compounds have a reasonable terminal elimination half-life of >2 h, and most compounds display low plasma clearance and volume distribution. Compound (8S,9R)-47 has excellent oral exposure and a significantly superior overall PK profile compared to that of the reference compound olaparib (AZD-2281). In beagle dog PK studies, the free base and tosylate salt also behaved very well, showing excellent bioavailability and oral exposure and a long half-life that could support a once-daily dosing regimen (Table 6). Moreover, (8S,9R)-47 demonstrated a favorable in vitro safety profile based on off-target, CYP450 isozyme, hERG, and Ames screenings (Table 7). Given its favorable PK and in vitro safety profiles, (8S,9R)-47 was further evaluated in in vivo xenograft tumor models.
    Table 5. Pharmacokinetic Parameters in Rat for Selected Compounds

    In Vivo Antitumor Studies of (8S,9R)-47(20)

    To assess the in vivo pharmacodynamics of (8S,9R)-47, MX-1 xenograft-bearing mice were given a single oral administration of 1 mg/kg (8S,9R)-47, and tumors were harvested at 2, 8, and 24 h post treatment. Intratumoral PAR levels were determined as described in the Experimental Section. Treatment with (8S,9R)-47 drastically reduced intratumoral PAR levels at 2 and 8 h, followed by only a partial recovery at 24 h (Figure 4a). This is in contrast to oral dosing of 100 mg/kg olaparib (AZD-2281), which resulted in significant PAR reduction only at 2 h post treatment, with partial recovery at 8 h and full recovery at 24 h.
    To assess in vivo antitumor effects of (8S,9R)-47 as a single agent, immunodeficient mice bearing established subcutaneous MX-1 tumor xenografts were treated with (8S,9R)-47.(20) Once-daily (QD) oral administration of 0.33 mg/kg (8S,9R)-47 for 28 consecutive days significantly inhibited xenograft MX-1 tumor growth, with four of six mice achieving a complete response (CR; tumor impalpable; Figure 4b). The lower dose of 0.1 mg/kg (8S,9R)-47 showed a limited and insignificant effect on tumor growth after extended treatment (>21 days; Figure 4b), but it still appeared to be more effective than olaparib (AZD-2281) dosed orally at 100 mg/kg QD. (8S,9R)-47 at these doses was well-tolerated, with no animal lethality or significant weight loss observed after 28 consecutive days of treatment.
    Because the PAR levels in mouse xenograft tumors started to recover between 8 and 24 h post administration of (8S,9R)-47 (Figure 4a), we tested whether twice-daily (BID) split-dosing may be more efficacious than QD dosing by comparing 0.33 mg/kg/dose QD vs 0.165 mg/kg/dose BID for 28 days in MX-1 xenogtraft mice.(20) Both dosing regimens were highly effective during the treatment period at inhibiting MX-1 tumor growth. However, while tumor growth in the QD cohort eventually reestablished after cessation of drug treatment, those in the BID cohort resulted in six of six CRs with no reestablishment of tumor growth even at 5 weeks after cessation of treatment (Figure 4c). These data suggest that continuous suppression of PARP1/2 is required for a sustained antitumor effect in the context of single-agent treatment and that, in mice, BID dosing of (8S,9R)-47 was preferred to achieve optimal therapeutic effects. It should be noted that half-life of (8S,9R)-47 in humans (∼40 h) is considerably longer than that in mice; QD dosing is sufficient in human patients to continuously suppress PARP and reach anticancer effects.(37, 38)
    The ability of (8S,9R)-47 to potentiate DNA-damaging anticancer agents was also assessed in xenograft tumor models.(20) MX-1 tumor-bearing mice were treated with 8 consecutive daily oral doses of (8S,9R)-47, olaparib, or vehicle (days 1–8). Cisplatin was dosed intraperitoneally at 6 mg/kg on day 3. (8S,9R)-47 at 0.1, 0.33, and 1 mg/kg demonstrated dose-dependent sensitization of cisplatin (Figure 5a). In a separate study, (8S,9R)-47 showed significant potentiation of carboplatin antitumor effects in vivo without significant overall toxicity (Figure 5b). (8S,9R)-47 also demonstrates extraordinary potentiation of alkylating agent temozolomide in a number of preclinical studies.(20, 39, 40)

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We have described the discovery and characterization of a novel, highly selective, and potent PARP1/2 inhibitor, (8S,9R)-47 (BMN 673; talazoparib). This compound represents a series of structurally unique, dual chiral-substituted tetrahydropyridophthalazinones that enable unique and extensive binding interactions with PARP1 and PARP2 proteins. Compound (8S,9R)-47 has demonstrated exceptionally potent in vitro antitumor activities, especially as a single-agent in BRCA1/2-deficient cells. Mounting evidence indicates that the ability of (8S,9R)-47 to strongly trap PARP proteins at least partially explains its exceptional tumor killing activity.(30, 32, 33) (8S,9R)-47 also displays favorable pharmacokinetic properties and in vitro safety profiles. The excellent potency and pharmacokinetic properties of this compound after oral administration translate into in vivo anticancer efficacy either as a single agent or as a chemosensitization agent in the BRCA1-deficient MX-1 breast cancer xenograft model and a number of other xenograft tumor models.
    The biological and pharmacological properties of (8S,9R)-47 warranted its further evaluation in clinical settings. In a phase 1 clinical trial in patients with solid tumors, (8S,9R)-47 was shown to be generally well-tolerated with inhibition of PARP activity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells occurring at oral doses as low as 100 μg/day.(37, 38) Single-agent anticancer activity was demonstrated in ovarian and breast cancers with deleterious germline BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation and in patients with small cell lung cancer.(41, 42) On the basis of these encouraging results, two late-phase clinical trials have been initiated using the recommended oral dose of 1 mg/day (8S,9R)-47: a phase 3 international, open-label, randomized, parallel, two-arm study in germline BRCA mutation subjects with locally advanced and/or metastatic breast cancer (EMBRACA)(43) and a phase 2 study in heavily pretreated breast cancer patients with germline BRCA mutations (ABRAZO).(44)

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis General

    Solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. The reference compounds ABT-888, AG-014699, AZD-2281, and MK-4827 were synthesized according to literature procedures.(15-19) HPLC-MS analyses were performed on an Agilent 1200 together with a MS 6110 using electrospray ionization (ESI). Prep-HPLC separations were carried out either on a Waters 2545 or Gilson GX-281. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were obtained on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 spectrometer and are referenced in ppm relative to TMS. Coupling constants (J) are expressed in hertz (Hz). Proton peak multiplicity is reported as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quintet), dd (doublet of doublets), m (multiplet), and bs (broad singlet). All final compounds displayed ≥95% purity (otherwise as noted), as determined by analytical RP-HPLC on an Agilent 1200 UV wavelengths of 214 and 254 nm.

    Chiral HPLC Separation and Analysis

    Chiral separation of racemic compounds was performed using preparative supercritical fluid chromatography (prep-SFC) on a Waters SFC-80 (Thar). Analytical SFC analyses were conducted on a Waters SFC method station (Thar). The chiral column used to resolve the enantiomers was either a CHIRALPACK IA, IC, or OJ-H. Retention times for the individual enantiomers are reported in minutes, whereas the ee (enantiomeric excess) values were calculated based on the UV absorption (at 254 nm) areas for the two enantiomers, respectively. Optical rotation of the chiral compounds was measured using a RUDOLPH (AUTOPOL V) automatic polarimeter.

    Synthesis of 4-Aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (7)

    A suspension of sodium borohydride (0.757 g, 20 mmol) in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF) (120 mL) was cooled to 0 °C. A solution of 4-nitrobenzofuran-1,3-dione (6.18 g, 32 mmol) in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (30 mL) was then added dropwise to the suspension. After the addition, the mixture was allowed to stir at this temperature for 3 h. The reaction was quenched with 3 N hydrochloric acid (to pH 1). Water (40 mL) was added to the mixture, which was then stirred for 1 h. THF was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was partitioned between water (150 mL) and ethyl acetate (150 mL × 3). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated to give a crude product. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 20:1 to 2:1) to give 4-nitroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (4.2 g, yield 73%) as a white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 180 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 5.77 (s, 3H), 7.32–7.34 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.81–7.85 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.29 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.55 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H).
    A suspension of 4-nitroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (1.0 g, 5.58 mmol) and 10% Pd/C (0.1 g) in ethyl acetate (30 mL) was purged in 1 atm hydrogen and stirred at 25 °C for 3 h. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated to give 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (7) (0.8 g, yield 96%) as an off-white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 150 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 3.82 (bs, 1H), 5.19 (s, 3H), 6.91–6.95 (m, 1H), 7.32–7.36 (m, 2H).

    Synthesis of Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-diaryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates (12, 14a–e)

    Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-diaryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (12)

    A mixture of 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (7) (0.4 g, 2.68 mmol) and benzaldehyde (0.72 g, 6.7 mmol) in ethyl propionate (20 mL) was cooled to 0 °C. Then, a solution of sodium methoxide in methanol [sodium (248 mg, 10.72 mmol) in methanol (20 mL)] was added dropwise. After the addition, the mixture was heated at reflux for 16 h. The mixture was quenched with water (10 mL) and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in water, acidified with 1 N hydrochloric acid to pH 6, and then extracted with ethyl acetate (50 mL × 3). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated to give a crude product, which was purified by prep-HPLC to give methyl 4-oxo-2,3-diphenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (12) (390 mg, yield 41%) as a light yellow solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 358 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 3.86 (s, 3H), 3.95–3.98 (d, J = 16.4 Hz, 1H), 4.81–4.84 (d, J = 12.8 Hz, 1H), 4.89 (s, br 1H), 6.72–6.77 (m, 2H), 6.90–6.93 (m, 2H), 7.11–7.21 (m, 8H), 7.34–7.36 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H).

    Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (14a)

    Compound 14a was synthesized by employing the procedure described for compound 12 using 4-pyridylaldehyde (268 mg, 2.5 mmol) in lieu of benzaldehyde and adjusting the other reagents proportionally to give 14a as a light yellow solid (60 mg, yield 17%). MS (ESI) m/z: 360 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (14b)

    Compound 14b was synthesized by employing the procedure described for compound 12 using 2-pyridylaldehyde (268 mg, 2.5 mmol) in lieu of benzaldehyde and adjusting the other reagents proportionally to give 14b as a light yellow solid (84 mg, yield 23%). MS (ESI) m/z: 360 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-di(3-pyridyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (14c)

    Compound 14c was synthesized by employing the procedure described for compound 12 using 3-pyridylaldehyde (535 mg, 5 mmol) in lieu of benzaldehyde and adjusting the other reagents proportionally. Purification was using column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 100:1 to 10:1) to give 14c as a light yellow solid (480 mg, yield 67%). MS (ESI) m/z: 360 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 4-Oxo-2,3-di(1-methyl imidazol-2-yl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (14d)

    Compound 14d was synthesized by employing the procedure described for compound 12 using 7 (298 mg, 2 mmol) and 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde (440 mg, 4 mmol) and adjusting the other reagents proportionally. Purification was using column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1 to 1) to give 14d as a light yellow solid (120 mg, yield 16%). MS (ESI) m/z: 366 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 2,3-Bis(4-((dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (14e)

    Compound 14e was synthesized by employing the procedure described for compound 12 using 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzaldehyde (539 mg, 3.3 mmol) and 7 (223 mg, 1.5 mmol) and adjusting the other reagents proportionally. Purification was using column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 100:1 to 10:1) to give 14e as a light yellow solid (165 mg, yield 23%). MS (ESI) m/z: 472 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 8,9-(Biaryl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-ones (13, 15–19)

    8,9-Diphenyl-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (13)

    A suspension of methyl 4-oxo-2,3-diphenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (12) (100 mg, 0.28 mmol) in 85% hydrazine monohydrate (25 mL) was heated to reflux for 20 h. The mixture was diluted with water (30 mL) and extracted with ethyl acetate (30 mL × 3). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated to give a crude product, which was purified by column chromatography (silica gel, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 20:1 to 8:1) to give compound 13 (15.6 mg, yield 16%) as a white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 340 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 4.22–4.24 (d, J = 8 Hz, 1H), 4.66–4.68 (d, J = 8 Hz, 1H), 4.89 (s, 1H), 7.02–7.06 (m, 3H), 7.16–7.26 (m, 8H), 7.57–7.61 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.74–7.76 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 9.82 (s, 1H).

    8,9-Di-(4-pyridyl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (15)

    Compound 15 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 14a (60 mg, 0.17 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using prep-HPLC to give 15 as a light yellow solid (15 mg, yield 26%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 4.46–4.48 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 4.90–4.92 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.16–7.20 (m, 3H), 7.32–7.34 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 2H), 7.40–7.42 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (s, 1H), 7.59–7.63 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.40–8.40 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 2H), 8.44–8.45 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 2H), 12.24 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 342 (M + H)+.

    8,9-Di-(2-pyridyl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (16)

    Compound 16 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 14b (68 mg, 0.19 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using prep-HPLC to give 16 as a light yellow solid (24 mg, yield 37%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 5.42–5.43 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 5.56–5.57 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 7.30–7.32 (d, J = 8.0 Hz,1H), 7.37–7.39 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.63–7.66 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 7.68–7.70 (m, 2H), 7.78–7.80 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.87–7.89 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 8.11–8.16 (m, 2H), 8.66–8.67 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 8.74–8.76 (d, J = 5.6 Hz, 1H), 10.69 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 342 (M + H)+.

    8,9-Di-(3-pyridyl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (17)

    Compound 17 was synthesized by employing a modified procedure for compound 13 using compound 14c (480 mg, 1.33 mmol) mixed with 85% hydrazine monohydrate (20 mL) and methanol (5 mL). Refluxed for 2 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered, affording 17 (320 mg, yield 70%) as a light yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 4.51–4.53 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 4.89–4.91 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.18–7.20 (d, 1H), 7.24–7.27 (m, 1H), 7.31–7.33 (m, 1H), 7.43–7.44 (d, 1H), 7.60 (s, 1H), 7.58–7.63 (m, 2H), 7.79–7.81 (m, 1H), 8.32–8.34 (m, 2H), 8.41–8.43 (m, 1H), 8.45–8.46 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 12.18 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 342 (M + H)+.

    8,9-Di-(1-methyl-imidazol-2-yl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (18)

    Compound 18 was synthesized by employing a modified procedure for compound 13 using compound 14d (120 mg, 0.32 mmol) mixed with 85% hydrazine monohydrate (2 mL) and methanol (3 mL). Stirred at room temperature for 3.5 h, the mixture was concentrated, filtered, and washed with methanol, affording 18 (45 mg, yield 39%) as a light yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 3.46 (s, 3H), 3.49 (s, 3H), 4.78–4.81 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 5.08–5.11 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 6.69 (s, 1H), 6.76–6.79 (m, 3H), 6.99–7.02 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.42–7.49 (m, 2H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 348 (M + H)+.

    8,9-Bis(4-((dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (19)

    Compound 19 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 14e (165 mg, 0.35 mmol) mixed with 85% hydrazine monohydrate (12 mL) and methanol (5 mL). Stirred at 40 °C for 6 h, the crude product was purified by prep-HPLC, affording 19 (34 mg, yield 21%) as a light yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 2.04 (s, 6H), 2.05 (s, 6H), 3.19–3.20 (m, 2H), 3.24–3.26 (m, 2H), 4.09–4.11 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 4.52–4.54 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 7.02–7.12 (m, 6H), 7.16–7.22 (m, 4H), 7.36–7.38 (d, 1H), 7.55–7.57 (t, 1H), 12.2 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 454 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 9-(Piperidin-3-yl)-8-(pyridin-3-yl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (20)

    A suspension of compound 17 (120 mg, 0.35 mmol) and platinum(IV) oxide (60 mg) in methanol (20 mL) was purged with 20 atm hydrogen and stirred at 50 °C for 24 h. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated to give a crude product, which was purified by prep-HPLC to give compound 20 (4 mg, yield 4%) as a light yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 1.19–1.32 (m, 2H), 1.60–1.65 (m, 2H), 1.94–1.97 (d, J = 10.0 Hz, 1H), 2.31–2.43 (m, 2H), 2.82–2.85 (d, J = 12.4 Hz, 1H), 3.02–3.05 (d, J = 12 Hz, 1H), 3.29–3.32 (dd, J1 = 2.8 Hz, J2 = 8.4 Hz,1H), 4.25–4.26 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.02–7.05 (dd, J1 = 0.8 Hz, J2 = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 7.22–7.25 (m, 1H), 7.40–7.53 (m, 3H), 8.25–8.29 (m, 2H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 348 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of (E)-4-((Arylmethylene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21a–k)

    (E)-4-((4-Fluorobenzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21f)

    To a stirred mixture of 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (3 g, 20.4 mmol) and anhydrous sodium sulfate (29 g, 20.4 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (200 mL) was added 4-aminoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one. The mixture was heated to reflux for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, it was filtered and the cake was washed with dichloromethane (50 mL × 3). The filtrate was concentrated to render a crude product, which was washed with petroleum ether to afford the title compound 21f (4.25 g, yield 81%) as a slightly yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 5.519 (s, 2H), 7.417 (dd, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.656 (m, 2H), 7.737 (dd, J1 = 5.6 Hz, J2 = 1.2 Hz, 1H), 8.042–8.079 (dd, J1 = 6 Hz, J2 = 3.2 Hz, 2H), 8.801 (s, 1H); LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 256 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-((4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)benzylidene)amino)-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21a)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzaldehyde (4 g, 24.5 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (4 g, 22.3 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21a was obtained as an off-white solid (3.7 g, yield 55%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 313 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 2.28 (s, 6H), 3.52 (s, 2H), 5.38–5.38 (m, 2H), 7.09–7.12 (m, 1H), 7.42–7.44 (m,1H), 7.46–7.48 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 7.87–7.89 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 8.51 (s, 1H).

    (E)-4-(Benzylideneamino)-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21b)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure described for 21f using benzaldehyde (4.125 g, 29.9 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (5 g, 29.9 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21b was obtained as an off-white solid (5 g, yield 66%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 256 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 5.40 (s, 2H); 7.11–7.14 (dd, J1 = 9.6 Hz, J2 = 2 Hz, 1H), 7.44–7.46 (dd, J1 = 6.8 Hz, J2 = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.52–7.59 (m, 3H), 7.93–7.95 (m, 2H), 8.54 (s, 1H).

    (E)-6-Fluoro-4-((4-fluorobenzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21c)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure described for 21f using 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1.67 g, 13.5 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (1.5 g, 8.98 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21c was obtained as a yellowish solid (0.85 g, yield 35%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 274 (M + H)+; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 5.37 (s, 2), 7.09–7.12 (dd, 1H), 7.19–7.23 (t, 2H), 7.43–7.45 (dd, 1H), 7.92–7.95 (m, 2H), 8.49 (s, 1H).

    (E)-4-(Benzylideneamino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21d)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using benzaldehyde (0.43 g, 4 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (0.6 g, 4 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21d was obtained as a white solid (0.9 g, yield 95%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 238 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 5.41 (s, 2H), 7.36–7.37 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.49–7.59 (m, 4H), 7.77–7.78 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.92–7.94 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 8.55 (s, 1H).

    (E)-4-((4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)benzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21e)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure described for 21f using 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzaldehyde (3.16 g, 19.4 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.89 g, 19.4 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21e was obtained as a light yellow solid (1.83 g, yield 32%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 295 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-((4-Chlorobenzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21g)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (2.3 g, 16.1 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.0 g, 13.4 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21g was obtained as an off-white solid (2.0 g, yield 55%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 272 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-((4-(Trifluoromethyl)benzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21h)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 4-(trifluoromethyl)benzaldehyde (2.8 g, 16.1 mmol) and 4-amino-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.0 g, 13.4 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21h was obtained as a yellowish solid (2.8 g, yield 68%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 306 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-(Benzylideneamino)-6-chloroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21i)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using benzaldehyde (0.72 g, 6.79 mmol) and 4-amino-6-chloroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one 7b (1.0 g, 5.46 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21i was obtained as a light yellow solid (0.74 g, yield 50%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 272 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-(((1-Methyl-1H-imidazol-2-yl)methylene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21j)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde (2.50 g, 23.0 mmol) and 4-amino-isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.80 g, 19.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21j was obtained as a white solid (5.0 g, yield 98%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 242 (M + H)+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 4.06 (s, 3H), 5.52 (s, 2H), 7.22 (s, 1H), 7.52 (s, 1H), 7.65–7.67 (m, 1H), 7.72–7.74 (m, 2H), 8.66 (s, 1H).

    (E)-4-((4-(Diethoxymethyl)benzylidene)amino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21k)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 4-(diethoxymethyl)benzaldehyde (3.75 g, 18.0 mmol) and 4-amino-isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.24 g, 15.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21k was obtained as a light yellow solid (4.3 g, yield 84%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 340 (M + H)+.

    (E)-4-(3-(Diethoxymethyl)benzylideneamino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21l)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 21f using 3-(diethoxymethyl)benzaldehyde (3.75 g, 18.0 mmol) and 4-amino-isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (2.24 g, 15.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 21k was obtained as a white solid (3.1 g, yield 61%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 340 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of Methyl or Ethyl 2,3-Disubstituted-4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylates (22a–u and 23a–h)

    Ethyl 3-(1-methyl-1H-imidazol-2-yl)-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22d)

    A mixture of (E)-4-(benzylideneamino)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21d) (500 mg, 2.1 mmol) and 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2- carbaldehyde (255 mg, 2.3 mmol) in ethyl propionate (20 mL) was cooled to 0 °C. Then, a solution of sodium ethoxide in ethanol [sodium (194 mg, 8.4 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL)] was added dropwise. After the addition, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h. The mixture was quenched with water (20 mL), and solvent was removed in vacuum. The residue was suspended in water and then filtered. The cake was washed with water and ethyl acetate to give a crude product, which was then purified with column chromatography on silica gel (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate 10:1 to 1:10) to give compound 22d as a yellow solid (140 mg, yield 18%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 1.18–1.21 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H), 3.31 (s, 3H), 4.16–4.19 (m, 2H), 4.56–4.59 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 5.14–5.17 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, 1H), 6.54–6.56 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 6.72 (s, 1H), 6.86 (s, 1H), 6.98–6.99 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 7.24–7.29 (m, 3H), 7.34–7.38 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.42–7.44 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 7.49 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 376 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 3-Isopropyl-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22a)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21d (237 mg, 1.0 mmol) and isobutyraldehyde (216 mg, 3.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 22a was obtained as a white solid (35 mg, yield 11%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 324 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 3-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22b)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21d (474 mg, 2.0 mmol) and 4-((dimethylamino)methyl)benzaldehyde (326 mg, 2.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 22b was obtained as a light yellow solid (166 mg, yield 20%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 415 (M + H)+.

    Methyl 3-(3-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22c)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21d (474 mg, 2.0 mmol) and 3-(diethoxymethyl)benzaldehyde (418 mg, 2.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a light yellow solid (230 mg, yield 25%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 1.05–1.09 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H), 3.27–3.31 (q, 4H), 3.68 (s, 3H), 4.22–4.25 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 4.96–4.99 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, 1H), 5.33 (s, 1H), 6.54–6.56 (dd, J1 = 7.2 Hz, J2 = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 6.98–7.00 (dd, J1 = 8.4 Hz, J2 = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.12–7.23 (m, 7H), 7.31–7.38 (m, 3H), 7.58 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 460 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 3-(1-Methyl-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22e)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21d (1.78g, 7.5 mmol) and 1-methyl-4H-1,2,4-triazole-5-carbaldehyde (1.01 g, 9.16 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 22e was obtained as a greenish solid (400 mg, yield 14%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 377 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 3-(4-Methyl-4H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)-4-oxo-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22f)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21d (634 mg, 2.7 mmol) and 4-methyl-4H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carbaldehyde (300 mg, 2.7 mmol) as the starting reagents. Compound 22f was obtained as a light yellow solid (51 mg, yield 5%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 377 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 2-(4-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-3-(4-fluorophenyl)-4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22g)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21k (10.8 g, 31.9 mmol) and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (3.95 g, 31.9 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a white solid (4.2 g, yield 26%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 492 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 2-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-3-(4-isopropylphenyl)-4-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22h)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21e (588 mg, 2.0 mmol) and 4-isopropylbenzaldehyde (296 mg, 2.0 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a light yellow solid (210 mg, yield 22%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 471 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 2-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-3-p-tolyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22i)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21e (500 mg, 1.70 mmol) and 4-methylbenzaldehyde (204 mg, 1.70 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a white solid (110 mg, yield 15%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 443 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 2-(4-((dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-3-(4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22j)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21e (541 mg, 1.84 mmol) and 4-(trifluoromethyl)benzaldehyde (320 mg, 1.84 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a light yellow solid (150 mg, yield 16%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 497 (M + H)+.

    Ethyl 2-(3-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-4-oxo-3-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline-5-carboxylate (22l)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 22d using 21l (678 mg, 2 mmol) and benzaldehyde (212 mg, 2.2 mmol) as the starting reagents. It was obtained as a white solid (160 mg, yield 17%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 474 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 8,9-Diaryl-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-ones (24, 28–51)

LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 397(M + H)+.

    Compound 46 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 22q (1.72 g, 4.4 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using column chromatography on silica gel to give 46 as a white solid (1.4 g, yield 90%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 3.65 (s, 3H), 4.91–5.00 (m, 2H), 7.12–7.19 (m, 3H), 7.39–7.43 (m, 2H), 7.47–7.50 (m, 2H), 7.58–7.60 (m, 1H), 7.79 (s, 1H), 12.22 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 363 (M + H)+.

    5-Fluoro-8-(4-fluorophenyl)-9-(1-methyl-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (47)

    Compound 47 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 23f (840 mg, 2.04 mmol) as the starting material. It was obtained as a white solid (650 mg, yield 84%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 3.66 (s, 3H), 4.97–5.04 (m, 2H), 6.91–6.94 (dd, J1 = 11.2 Hz, J2 = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.06–7.09 (dd, J1= 8.8 Hz, J2 = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.14–7.18 (m, 2H), 7.47–7.51 (m, 2H), 7.72 (s, 1H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 12.35 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 381 (M + H)+. Anal. Calcd for C19H14F2N6O·H2O: C, 57.29; H, 4.05; N, 21.10. Found: C, 57.37; H, 4.09; N, 21.21.

    8-(4-(Dimethoxymethyl)phenyl)-9-phenyl-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (48)

    Compound 48 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 22m (120 mg, 0.28 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using column chromatography on silica gel to give 48 as a white solid (89 mg, yield 78%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 414 (M + H)+.

    9-(3-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-8-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (49)

    Compound 49 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 22c (300 mg, 0.65 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using column chromatography on silica gel to give 49 as a white solid (95 mg, yield 33%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 1.04–1.08 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 6H), 3.27–3.31 (q, 4H), 4.34–4.36 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 4.74–4.76 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 5.34 (s, 1H), 7.08 (s, 1H), 7.14–7.24 (m, 7H), 7.27–7.29 (m, 2H), 7.37–7.39 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.43 (s, 1H), 7.56–7.60 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 12.15 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 442 (M + H)+.

    8-(3-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-9-phenyl- 8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (50)

    Compound 50 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 22l (160 mg, 0.36 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using column chromatography on silica gel to give 50 as a white solid (90 mg, yield 58%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 442 (M + H)+.

    8-(4-(Diethoxymethyl)phenyl)-9-(4-fluorophenyl)-8,9-dihydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3(7H)-one (51)

    Compound 51 was synthesized by employing the procedure for compound 13 using compound 22g (4.2 g, 8.54 mmol) as the starting material. Purification was performed using column chromatography on silica gel to give 51 as a white solid (3.0 g, yield 76%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 460 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of (3-Oxo-8 (9)-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-9-yl)benzaldehyde derivatives (48a–51a)

    4-(3-Oxo-9-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-8-yl)benzaldehyde (48a)

    A mixture of compound 48 (89 mg, 0.22 mmol) and 3 N hydrochloric acid (20 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting mixture was neutralized with potassium carbonate and then filtered to give compound 48a as a white solid (59 mg, yield 73%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 368 (M + H)+.

    3-(3-Oxo-8-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-9-yl)benzaldehyde (49a)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 48a using 49 (90 mg, 0.20 mmol) as the starting material. It was obtained as a white solid (66 mg, yield 88%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 368 (M + H)+.

    3-(3-oxo-9-Phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-8-yl)benzaldehyde (50a)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 48a using 50 (90 mg, 0.21 mmol) as the starting material. It was obtained as a light yellow solid (40 mg, yield 50%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ (ppm) 4.24 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.77 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 4.85 (brs, 1H), 7.01–7.03 (m, 2H), 7.08–7.10 (m, 1H), 7.21–7.24 (m, 3H), 7.37–7.39 (m, 2H), 7.61–7.65 (m, 1H), 7.74–7.75 (m, 2H), 7.79–7.81 (m, 1H), 9.59 (brs, 1 H), 9.92 (s, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 368 (M + H)+.

    4-(9-(4-Fluorophenyl)-3-oxo-3,7,8,9-tetrahydro-2H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-8-yl)benzaldehyde (51a)

    This compound was synthesized in the same manner as that for 48a using 51 (3.0 g, 6.53 mmol) as the starting material. It was obtained as a light yellow solid (2.5 g, yield 98%). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 386 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 8(9)-((Alkylamino)methyl)phenyl)-9(8)-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one derivatives (25–27, 52–57)

    9-(3-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-8-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (26)

    A mixture of 4a (45 mg, 0.12 mmol) and 33% dimethylamine solution (50.2 mg, 0.366 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. After cooling to 0 °C, sodium borohydride (6.95 mg, 0.184 mmol) was added to the mixture. It was stirred at this temperature for 2 h. Methanol was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC to give 26 (21 mg, yield 44%) as a light yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 2.59 (s, 3H), 2.75 (s, 3H), 4.11–4.27 (q, 2H), 4.31–4.34 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1H), 4.68–4.71 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1H), 7.17–7.30 (m, 9H), 7.33–7.37 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.56–7.58 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.60–7.64 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 397 (M + H)+.

    8-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-9-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (25)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 26 using 48a (59 mg, 0.16 mmol) as the starting material. Compound 25 was obtained as a light yellow solid (20 mg, yield 32%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 2.79 (s, 6H), 4.23 (s, 2H), 4.31–4.33 (d, J = 8 Hz, 1H), 4.81–4.83 (d, J = 8 Hz, 1H), 7.08–7.1 (m, 2H), 7.10–7.22 (m, 4H), 7.34–7.36 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 7.41–7.43 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 7.55–7.56 (d, J = 8 Hz, 1H), 7.57–7.65 (t, J = 8 Hz, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 397 (M + H)+.

    8-(3-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-9-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (27)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 26 using 50a (50 mg, 0.14 mmol) as the starting material. Compound 27 was obtained as a light yellow solid (34 mg, yield 64%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 2.17 (s, 6H), 3.17–3.41 (q, 2H), 4.31 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.74 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.08–7.10 (m, 2H), 7.13–7.25 (m, 8H), 7.55–7.57 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.61–7.65 (m, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 397 (M + H)+.

    8-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-9-(4-fluorophenyl)-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (52)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 26 using 51a (80 mg, 0.21 mmol) as the starting material. Compound 52 was obtained as a light yellow solid (21 mg, yield 24%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 2.82 (s, 6H), 4.26 (s, 2H), 4.32 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.77 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.93–6.95 (m, 2H), 7.10–7.11 (m, 2 H), 7.23 (m, 1H), 7.40–7.41 (m, 4H), 7.59 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H). 19F NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) −77.09, −118.00. LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 415 (M + H)+.

    8-(4-((4-Methylpiperazin-1-yl)methyl)phenyl)-9-phenyl-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (53)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 26 using 48a (150 mg, 0.40 mmol) and N-methyl-piperazine (123 mg, 1.2 mmol) as the starting materials. Compound 52 was obtained as a light yellow solid (36 mg, yield 19%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ (ppm) 2.29 (s, 3H), 2.12–2.73 (br s, 8H), 3.47 (s, 2H), 4.30 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.74 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.08–7.10 (m, 2H), 7.18–7.21 (m, 6 H), 7.23–7.25 (m, 2H), 7.55–7.57 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.62–7.64 (m, 1H). LC-MS (ESI) m/z: 452 (M + H)+.

    9-Phenyl-8-(4-(pyrrolidin-1-ylmethyl)phenyl)-2,7,8,9-tetrahydro-3H-pyrido[4,3,2-de]phthalazin-3-one (54)

    This compound was synthesized by employing the procedure for 26 using 48a (367 mg, 1.00 mmol) and pyrrolidine (213 mg, 3.00 mmol) as the starting materials. Compound 54 was obtained as a white solid (62 mg, yield 14%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ (ppm) 1.82–1.85 (m, 2H), 1.97 (s, 2H), 3.01–3.05 (m, 2H), 3.26 (d, 2H), 4.27 (d, 2H), 4.36 (d, 1H), 4.84 (d, 1H), 7.13–7.23 (m, 6H), 7.36–7.40 (m, 5H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 7.57–7.61 (t, 1H), 12.18 (s, 1H).
